Award.AwardTitle: Development and study of new generation of ultrabright fluorescent FRET-based sensing nanoparticles

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1605405

Fluorescence is a powerful optical tool in biology and medicine. While the majority of fluorophores are used for imaging, some of them can also be utilized to detect the presence of particular ions. Fluorophores can also be functionalized to adhere to specific chemical structures. While being highly desirable, it is extremely difficult to create molecular fluorophores which can be functionalized and work as sensors. Fluorescent nanoparticles (NPs) offer a unique combination by having a fluorescent sensing core and a functionalizable surface.

The PI proposes to develop a new generation of bright fluorescent silica NPs that will work as sensors and be functionalizable with a variety of molecules. The proposed hybrid fluorescent nanoparticles (NPs) are novel and pioneered by the PI. The significantly improved brightness of the NPs could enable many applications that were previously impossible. The proposed super bright hybrid NPs would become a powerful tool for many biomedical applications that are not addressable with fluorescent dyes. The educational impact will include the direct exposure of the research to his graduate student and his post-doc on the grant, the PI has and will continue to involve undergraduates in the research. He will incorporate the research findings into existing courses he teaches and will maintain existing outreach efforts and public presentations in high schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Attaining ultrabright fluorescence in silica nanoparticles by using a nanoporous environment for encapsulation traditional fluorescent dyes

By controlling self-assembly of nanoporous silica nanoparticles, a team of scientists from Tufts University has demonstrated the development of ultrabright fluorescent silica nanoparticles (Star dots). The Star dots are up to several hundred times brighter than the presently available commercial rivals, quantum dots. The phenomenon of ultrabright fluorescence was explained by a specific nanoscale environment, which is created during the self-assembly of Star dots. The researchers showed that practically any existing fluorescent dye molecules could be encapsulated in such an environment without the need for chemical changing of the dye molecules.

By combining different fluorescent dyes within each particle, the researchers created ultrabright fluorescent sensors of temperature and acidity. The high brightness of the sensors allows doing the measurements in the vicinity of each nanoparticle, which was not previously possible. It allows going deeper into the study of the physical and chemical machinery of biological cells, the fundamental bricks of life. Furthermore, a combination of multiple dyes within each particle allows creating a practically unlimited number of distinguishable fluorescence spectra.  It can be used in flow cytometry to accelerate this technique to detect diseased cells faster and with much higher accuracy.

In collaboration with Boston University, the researchers have shown the ability of Star dots to visualize malignant tumors in zebrafish model with high speed and accuracy. Star dots are accumulated in melanoma tumors within 30 minutes, highlighting it with bright fluorescence. These results will be used in the development of visualization of tumors for the purpose of detection and the increase of accuracy in cancer surgery. In partnership with Dartmouth College Medical School, the scientists demonstrated the ability of the approach to create an advanced temperature control of magnetic nanoparticles, which can be used during hyperthermia treatment of cancer. This control is based on the reading of fluorescence signals coming from a specially designed shall surrounding magnetic particles that heat the tumor. It is expected to increase the efficiency of this treatment.

This grant helped to support the training of four postdoctoral fellows, five Ph.D. students, and four undergraduate students (students from three different states participated in this multidisciplinary activity).
